Authors:
Elisha Thynne, Megan C McDonald, Margaret Evans, Hugh
Wallwork, Stephen M Neate, Peter S Solomon
Title:
Re-classification of the causal agent of white grain disorder
on wheat as three separate species of Tiarosporella
Keywords:
Botryosphaeriaceae, Botryosphaeria zeae, phylogeny, wheat
grain, Tiarosporella
Abstract:
Abstract In the late 1990s, a novel Botryosphaeria-like
fungal pathogen was observed causing a disease in Queensland,
characterized as white grain disorder (WGD). In recent years, this
disease has sporadically appeared across the eastern states of
Australia. In this study, internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region
sequences were used to compare these fungi to other Botryosphaeriaceae
spp. to show that they should be reclassified as members of the
Tiarosporella genus. Using a small population of WGD isolates, we built
a three-loci maximum likelihood tree, using ITS, β-tubulin, and
Elongation Factor1-α sequences to show that there are three separate
Tiarosporella spp. found in infected grain. This multigene tree, with
the support of phenotypic differences between clades observed in vitro,
show that that the causal agents of WGD should be delimited into three
divergent species; Tiarosporella tritici-australis, Tiarosporella
darliae, and Tiarosporella pseudodarliae.
